Award.AwardTitle: Eyespot Placement and Assembly in Chlamydomonas

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT
This research uses the model organism Chlamydomonas reinhardtii to understand how complex molecular structures are assembled at specific locations within a cell. Chlamydomonas is a single-celled, photosynthetic alga found in freshwater habitats throughout the world. Chlamydomonas cells optimize photosynthesis by swimming toward or away from light using two flagella (the mother flagellum and the daughter flagellum) at the anterior end of the cell. Light intensity and direction are sensed by the eyespot, a complex structure that is always found at the outer edge of the cell, half way between the anterior and posterior ends of the cell, on the same side of the cell as the daughter flagellum. The eyespot contains photoreceptor proteins that are similar to the rhodopsins in mammalian eyes, and a variety of other proteins that are located in the cell membrane layers or lipid granules that are unique to the eyespot. This research will test the hypothesis that the photoreceptor proteins are required for the assembly and/or placement of the eyespot, and will identify and characterize other proteins involved in eyespot formation. A molecular model of eyespot assembly resulting from this research will be applicable to studies of a wide variety of other sub-cellular structures in other biological systems.

BROADER IMPACTS
Chlamydomonas has long been a model organism for the study of photosynthesis and flagellar assembly, so the conditions for growth, genetic manipulation, and molecular characterization of this photosynthetic alga are well established. Studying the Chlamydomonas eyespot is, therefore, an excellent model system for training the diverse group of young scientists pursuing degrees at the University of Arizona. A number of undergraduate and graduate students have completed their senior, honor, or Ph. D. theses studying eyespot assembly, and University of Arizona students continue to pursue eyespot-related research. Additionally, established relationships with two small college professors and their students will continue. Because the grass-green Chlamydomonas cell with its bright orange eyespot and long flagella is easily viewed through the light microscope, visiting the laboratory has also been popular with grade school students. In response, the researchers have developed Chlamydomonas-based biology lessons that will be presented to K-12 students in their classrooms. Chlamydomonas is only one of a very large number of photosynthetic microorganisms that respond to light. Student interest in Chlamydomonas is increasing as these microorganisms become the focus of efforts to produce food and fuel using energy from the sun.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Animals and plants are made up of a huge number of individual cells.  The development and function of multicellular tissues and organisms is dependent on individual cell architecture. Each cell is like a separate room. We want to understand how the inside of cells are organized. To make that easier, we study single cells that are similar to each other.

Intellectual merit:

The single algal cells we study are green, and like plants, photosynthesize. They have several of the same internal compartments as all animal and plant cells: nucleus (where the DNA is), mitochondria (energy engines), and like all plant cells they have chloroplasts (the green place for photosynthesis). The particular species of algae we study, Chlamydomonas, has a special internal compartment or organelle called the eyespot. The eyespot senses light and sends signals to the flagella (extended "arms") to swim in the right direction so that the cell gets just the right amount of light for photosynthesis. The overall goal of this study was to understand how the eyespot is constructed and placed in the exact location in the cell that allows it to function properly.

One interesting thing about the eyespot is that it is made up of a lot of different membrane layers, like a double-decker sandwich with four different kinds of bread, and layers of ball-like structures pressed in-between. To work properly, the layers have to stick together and the balls have to be packed tightly. In the work supported by the NSF, we have discovered two special proteins that glue the layers togther. We have also discovered a protein that is required for the "ball" structures to form.

The second interesting thing about the eyespot is that there is only one, and it has to be in a special place in the cell so that the signal from the eyespot to the flagella has the right timing between when the eyespot sees the light and the flagella respond. If it is in the wrong place, the timing will be off and the cell will swim in the wrong direction. We have discovered a protein that guides the placement of the eyespot when it is being constructed (this happens every time new cells are formed by division of an older cell). So, by studying single cells, we are learning how the inside of cells are organized in three dimensions, and how the cellular "furniture" is built and placed precisely, so that everything works correctly.

Broader Impacts:

Two areas where this grant has had broader impacts are in science education and public outreach. 

1) K-12 science education and outreach: Dr. Nadja Anderson is K-12 Outreach Director for the Molecular and Cellular Biology Department. She reaches thousands of students, teachers and parents every year with her demonstrations, lessons and projects. Every year, this award has provided Dr. Anderson's program with partial salary and supply support. Also, we have provided wild-type and blind strains of Chlamydomonas for demonstrations, and advice on procedures.

2) Curriculum development: Dr. Molly Bolger, Assistant Professor in the Molecular and Cellular Biology Department, and postdoc, Dr. Susan Hester, used a quarter of the Dieckmann lab space in the 2016-2017 academic year to develop a new block of four lab exercises (4 hours each, 16 hours total) for the freshman biology class at the University of Arizona. The goal of the new block is to encourage students to develop and test their own hypotheses about how Chlamydomonas uses its eyespot to see and direct the flagella to swim to the correct location. Dr. Bolger's research shows that having students direct and analyze their own experiments leads to better understanding of science. We provided materials, protocols, procedures, troubleshooting, and help with evaluation of the student results at the end of the Spring semester. The plan going forward is to continue to use this block of exercises for freshman biology on this campus and provide information to others for use on other campuses.

3) Directed research/underserved students: Many students at the undergraduate and graduate level have engaged in directed research on the Chlamydomonas eyespot in the Dieckmann lab. All students must disseminate their findings in a term paper, senior and/or Honors Thesis, or PhD dissertation. Three students have earned their PhD studying the eyespot, one from an underserved population. Another underserved graduate student earned an MS and is now an RN involved in advanced training. An underserved post-baccalaureate student has started a Pharmacology PhD program. I have been in charge of underserved graduate student recruiting for five years.

4) Public service and education: Throughout the tenure of this award, lab members have been active in organizing and judging in local school science fairs. In summer 2016, I gave four public lectures in Tucson on: What is: a) a virus? b) a cell? c) a chromosome? d) a gene?
